text: You guys, I'm glad it's 2017.
I know 2017 has been a weird year.
But here's why I'm glad.
I feel like we're not celebrating
things that we've overcome.
You guys, 2016 was the year
that "Clown-mageddon" happened.
Do you remember this?
Clowns were just terrorizing people in the streets?
Like all over the country.
And it ended we just forgot about it. We did.
We should be celebrating this
as a coordinated clown effort.
And I don't want to brag but I was kind of following it
before it was a big deal.
I got a hit on my 'Creepy Clowns' Google Alert.
I was so excited!
Here's what the first article said.
The first article about clown-mageddon read like this.
It said, "In a town in North Carolina
children are being lured into the forest
by clowns or people dressed as clowns."
(Audience laughs. They are with him)
I think you guys are with me.
Aren't all clowns just people dressed as clowns?
Are we really worried about whether or not
they graduated from an accredited Clown College
at this point?
Did they interview the Dean? He's like,
"I don't know who these 'tree clowns' think they are.
But they did not graduate from a proud 'clown-iversity'
such as ours."
And yeah, Provo, in the clown community
they prefer "clown-iversity'" over "clown college".
"Clown college" is kind of insensitive so "stay woke".
Or maybe the newspaper was just worried
about being politically correct. They want to be PC.
And they're like, "Look, maybe they look like clowns
but they identify as mimes.
Who are we?..."
(Raucous and very much deserved applause)
But I started... I started thinking like
why was I attracted these stories?
Like, why did I have a "creepy clowns" Google Alert?
And I started thinking about
the characteristics of clowns.
If you look at clowns, really three things come to mind:
goofy red hair, pale white skin,
for the third let's say atypical body types.
Like, I've been a redheaded stepchild my entire life.
But I think I found my people.
I think I found them.
Thank you.
And I get it. I get it.
They're like terrorizing people in the streets,
luring kids into the forest.
But like I think I could do it.
I think I'd fit in.
